title: SHO energy - block 1 and block 2 collide on spring

content.question:
The figures show a horizontal spring, a horizontal surface, and two identical blocks, Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. Initially, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, only Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is attached to the spring and oscillates in simple harmonic motion while Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is held above the surface. At a later time shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is instantaneously at rest and Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is dropped onto Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> from above. The blocks then move together without slipping, as shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>. There is negligible friction between Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and the surface.
